page.title: 03 ECOLOGY OF LEWES
page.content: On the{Ouse floodplain,}the alluvial soils are drained for farming so reed and marsh vegetation only survive in small patches. The Pells, Lewes, has been protected from devel- opment in order to preserve its fragile Wetland ecosystem. On the thin soils of the{Chalk {Downs}flourishes a rich grassland flora with orchids, scabious, cowslips alive with butterflies such as the Marbled White. After clearance of ash and beech woodland, past sheep grazing has maintained the grassland stage; intensive cereal cultivation now restricts it to the steeper slopes. Jackdaws nest and wallflowers grow in crevices on river and quarry{cliffs. {In the town,}rooks nest in the elms in this Dutch Elm Control Area. The old flint walls have a rich flora,eg. ivy-leaved toadflax.
